Posts.Content: I was surprised that they did not take out some of lymph nodes in the vicinity. Are you at a good place getting treatments where docs deal with a lot of breast cancers? I don't know much about male vs female variants. But I know that cancer can grow in any cells that have DNA.

Posts.Title: Male breast cancer - please share your stories

Posts.Content: Even if you plan to have more kids, you don't need your breasts. I would do both breasts and everything below the waist if it's an option. There is a list of body parts at NCI that we can live without. And those body parts that I mentioned are on the list. So get rid of them.

Posts.Title: New to site and scared

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kombis Dear Gerber, Please provide update. I am investigating this treatment and considering it for my bladder cancer treatment. Contact me directly if you wish. I agree that it's a scam. It maybe ok for the protection of the bladder from chemo (very not convinced), but not for cancer treatment. I also have a bladder cancer (and lymphoma). Actually by BC is thought to be a secondary cancer after chemo and rads. Please, don't do unreliable drugs, it's dangerous. What grade and stage is it? Just drink a lot of water and eat good stuff.

Posts.Title: New side-effect free chemo? Really?

Posts.Content: I had an excisional biopsy of my 6 cm lymph node in the armpit and I had a huge seroma after the surgery. It bothered me for many months, it was full of liquid and very hard. I went twice to the emergency, anyway after 6 months it finally got better. Now I even don't remember about it.

Posts.Title: 3 months and more swelling

Posts.Content: cutepathgen, I don't know anything about your doc or your cancer. But I can give you a general advice. Get educated about your type of cancer, read papers about new treatments. The good thing is that your family member goes to Sloan, they are the NCI designated center and are on top of all breakthroughs. I will give you some good news. The biggest breakthrough in cancer is immunotherapy. I imagine first type of treatment will be chemo/radio and it will give some relief for some time, but if the cancer returns and nothing works, then the best bet is to get into clinical trials for immunotherapy. They are doing miracles for some patients and the more researchers understand how it works, the more people will benefit. Just google immunotherapy and learn about it. To start this is the best link http://www.cancerresearch.org/cancer...ng-all-cancers

Posts.Title: Opinions on Dr. Mahmoud El-Tamer at MSKCC for Stage 3 Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: The result depends on the many factors like if the tumor is immunogenic, in other words, attracts a lot of cytotoxic T cells. Some tumors are invisible to them as tumors are our own cells. But if the tumor cells are very abnormal they might become visible and T cells might infiltrate the tumor and start killing it. However, cancer has a way to deactivate them so the pd1 inhibitors reactivate them back. Most people don't report any side effects, maybe some tiredness, but few people had strong side effects and had to stop. PD1 inhibitors (opdivo and keytruda) are very effective in bladder cancer, kidney cancer, melanoma and lung cancer. The PD-L1 inhibitors are also in trials (from Roche and some others). They prevent inactivation of T cells by inhibiting the substrate of PD1 that is expressed on tumor cells.

Posts.Title: Anyone in PD-L1 inhibitor trials?

Posts.Content: I think that is a metastatic breast cancer. It usually spreads to bones and dissolves them. Secondary cancer is a different cancer (different cell of origin) that can arise from some chemicals, drugs or radiation. I have a secondary bladder carcinoma in addition to the lymphoma after it was radiated in the groin area.

Posts.Content: Natalie, there is no diet that can stop cancer. Just eat normal diet, soups, more fish, fruits and veggies. Drink more water, especially during chemo. Don't smoke. Exercise. Take anti excitement medication.
